sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying generator
message_1: A generator has a circular coil of 200 turns and a radius of 0.5 m. It is carrying an electric current of 10 A. What is the magnitude of the magnetic field at the center of the coil?
message_2:
To find the magnetic field at the center of the coil, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a circular loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * N) / (2 * R)

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10⁻⁷ Tm/A), I is the current, N is the number of turns, and R is the radius of the coil.

Given the values:
I = 10 A
N = 200 turns
R = 0.5 m

We can plug these values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10⁻⁷ Tm/A * 10 A * 200) / (2 * 0.5 m)

B = (8π × 10⁻⁶ T * 200) / 1

B = 1600π × 10⁻⁶ T

B ≈ 5.027 × 10⁻³ T

The magnitude of the magnetic field at the center of the coil is approximately 5.027 × 10⁻³ T (Tesla).
